items.title: ‘Science demands action’: world leaders and UN push climate agenda forward despite Trump’s attacks
items.content_html:
Leaders unveil new targets to cut planet-heating pollution after Trump called climate crisis a ‘con job’

World leaders have unveiled new targets to cut planet-heating pollution at the United Nations, in a bid to spur fresh impetus to the beleaguered climate effort a day after Donald Trump called the crisis “the greatest con job ever perpetrated upon the world”.

A total of 120 countries and the European Union announced new goals to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in New York on Wednesday. The pledges most notably include one from China, the world’s leading emitter, which said it would cut emissions by 7-10% from its peak level by 2035.

items.title: Jaguar Land Rover is a rich company – it can pay to support its own supply chain | Nils Pratley
items.content_html:
As the government explores options to support suppliers it should ensure that the carmaker foots the eventual bill

Here are a few principles for the government to bear in mind as it contemplates intervening to support car component suppliers hit by the fallout from the cyber-attack on Jaguar Land Rover.

First, JLR is a large and rich company that should support its direct suppliers itself – indeed, it will often have a contractual obligation to do so. Second, any intervention should be aimed at firms that are more exposed because their relationship with JLR is indirect – the suppliers to the suppliers, as it were. Third, even in the latter case, there is a fair argument that ministers should try to strong-arm JLR into picking up the eventual bill. One aim, after all, is to ensure that JLR’s eventual return to production is as smooth as possible.

Continue reading...

items.title: Trump’s pro-Kyiv pivot raises stakes: Will EU release €200 B in frozen Russian assets to Ukraine?
items.content_html: Bart M. J. Szewczyk, Author, nonresident Senior Fellow at the German Marshall Fund and adjunct professor at Sciences Po, joins Genie Godula to break down Donald Trump’s latest rhetorical pivot on Russia. The US president’s recent remarks, suggesting Ukraine could “win back all of its territory”, mark a significant departure from his administration’s previously ambivalent and sympathetic stance toward Moscow. While Mr. Szewczyk cautions against taking Trump’s pronouncements at face value, he acknowledges “it is a big diplomatic shift and time will tell whether it translates into additional economic pressure against Russia and greater military support to Ukraine.”

items.title: Amid death spiral of war, militancy, and genocide, is two-state solution politically unattainable?
items.content_html: The collapse of the two‑state paradigm is not the failure of a single actor. The Israeli and Palestinian leaderships, Arab states, international mediators, Europe, the United States, and the United Nations all bear some level of responsibility for the void we now confront. For our Special Report, we are pleased to bring together our International Affairs Commentator Douglas Herbert and two guest experts whose analyses diverge sharply: Steven Ekovich, Professor Emeritus of Political Science at American University of Paris, offers us a historical lens grounded in power politics and statecraft and Noura Erakat, Human Rights Attorney and Professor at Rutgers University, whose framework centres on justice, law, human rights, and the asymmetries of power.

items.title: Australia’s horrifying climate future in four charts – and how we can avoid the worst
items.content_html:
Maps released by the Australian Climate Service show just how bad things will get for heatwaves, drought and coastal flooding

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

Australia’s national climate risk assessment report, released last week, revealed a horrifying future if urgent action to address global heating was not taken.

The report looked at 10 “priority hazards” – such as bushfires, flooding and extreme heat – and the risks they presented across Australia’s way of life (you can read about the key takeaways from the report here).

items.title: Callan park master plan hopes to turn former mental hospital site into ‘iconic’ urban parkland
items.content_html:
Exclusive: NSW government plan proposes restoring native bushland and upgrading heritage buildings for cafes and possible film studio by 2035, but leaves unanswered questions over how project would be paid for

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

A new master plan for Callan park, the site of a former mental hospital in Sydney’s inner west, proposes restoring the heritage buildings for health and cultural uses and possibly for a film facility while rejuvenating its extensive parklands to create a second Centennial park-style green space for the city.

But it has left unanswered questions over how the project would be paid for, raising questions about whether the vision can be achieved by 2035, especially as many of the heritage buildings that were once part of the hospital require extensive renovation.

Continue reading...

items.title: WA ‘ready to fight’ to keep contentious $60bn GST deal as Chalmers orders distribution review
items.content_html:
State treasurer expects bipartisan support in Canberra for existing deal will prevent changes, as NSW backs review of ‘busted’ system

  • Get our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcast

A deal that will hand an estimated extra $60bn in tax revenue to Western Australia over a decade will come under scrutiny after Jim Chalmers tasked the Productivity Commission with reviewing the GST distribution.

The treasurer on Wednesday released the terms of reference for the scheduled Productivity Commission review in 2026, acknowledging that the GST carve-up between the states and territories “will always be a contentious issue”.

Yu, 62, was flying to a ranch in Mato Grosso do Sul state, near Brazil’s western border with Paraguay and Bolivia, in a single-engine four-seater Cessna aircraft when the plane went down on Tuesday afternoon.

items.title: US' Donald Trump 'is making a major pivot on Ukraine'
items.content_html: President Donald Trump has dramatically shifted his position on Ukraine, surprising many in diplomatic circles. Just a month ago, Trump suggested that Ukraine would need to make concessions in the ongoing conflict. Now, he claims he believes Ukraine can retake all its lost territory. UN diplomats describe this sudden reversal as a sign of Trump’s unpredictability and a potential risk to diplomatic efforts, as FRANCE 24's Jessica Le Masurier explains from New York.

items.title: Horror film digitally altered in China to make gay couple straight
items.content_html:
Viewers outraged after same-sex wedding scene changed in Together, starring Dave Franco and Alison Brie

An Australian horror film featuring a scene with a same-sex wedding was reportedly digitally altered for release in mainland China, transforming the gay couple into a heterosexual one, provoking outrage from viewers who spotted the change.

The critically acclaimed film Together, starring Dave Franco and Alison Brie, was released in selected cinemas in China on 12 September. It follows the journey of a young couple who move to the countryside and encounter mysterious and grotesque changes to their bodies.

Fierce winds, pounding rain and high seas battered Hong Kong as Super Typhoon Ragasa headed into southern China after causing a lake to burst in Taiwan, killing at least 17 people.

items.title: ‘We are at our limit’: Gaza’s last hospitals overwhelmed as thousands flee south
items.content_html:
‘Not enough of anything’, says surgeon, as Israel’s assault forces injured, sick and hungry people to leave Gaza City

The few remaining hospitals and clinics in central and southern Gaza are being overwhelmed by a “tsunami” of injured and sick patients fleeing a new Israeli offensive in the north of the devastated territory, medics say.

At both Nasser medical complex, in the southern city of Khan Younis, and field hospitals in al-Muwasi, the coastal “humanitarian zone” designated by Israel, staff are struggling to cope with large numbers of new arrivals forced out of Gaza City in the north of the devastated Palestinian territory.

items.title: Brazil’s president says in UN speech that democracy can prevail over ‘would-be autocrats’
items.content_html:
South American leftist Lula takes indirect swipes at Trump in speech and warns that global threat of ‘anti-democratic forces’ persists

Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, Brazil’s president, has launched an impassioned defence of his country’s democracy, claiming the recent conviction of his far-right predecessor, Jair Bolsonaro, had shown the world how “would-be autocrats” could be brought to heel.

Speaking at the opening of the United Nations general assembly in New York, Lula hailed Brazil’s successful effort to repel “an unprecedented attack” from Bolsonaro’s extreme right movement. On 11 September, the former paratrooper was sentenced to 27 years in jail for trying to stage a military coup after he lost the 2022 election to Lula.

The head of Quebec’s police watchdog said it will investigate the death of a 15-year-old boy who was shot dead by officers, revealing that the only weapon recovered from the scene of the fatal shooting belonged to the police.

items.title: Ice targeted me for organizing, says farm worker who left US for Mexico
items.content_html:
Alfredo Juarez Zeferino spent a harrowing few months in Ice jail – and, under threat of deportation, chose to leave

Alfredo “Lelo” Juarez Zeferino spends much of his days outdoors, harvesting bananas and hiking vast, bramble-laden trails. But for more than a quarter of 2025, he barely saw the sun. After being arrested by Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) in March, the farm-worker activist was placed in a detention center in Washington state, where he remained until he agreed to voluntarily leave the US.

“I probably would say five times, in the three months and a half I was in there, they offered me to go outside,” he explained on a Zoom call from his family farm in Guerrero, Mexico, where he has been for more than a month.

“There is indeed something about captivity that makes one feel like a state of somewhere between life and death,” wrote Umar Khalid in June in a letter penned as his fifth year languishing behind bars approached.

Few understand the purgatory of jail like Khalid. For five years – since his arrest in September 2020 under a draconian terrorism law – he has remained India’s most prominent political prisoner, to many a potent symbol of the systematic crushing of dissent under the dominant Hindu nationalist regime of the prime minister, Narendra Modi.

items.content_html: Author Ayelet Gundar-Goshen writes to challenge fear and prejudice, taking a humanist perspective on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Her new novel is a plea for empathy and self-reflection.

items.title: Russia and Ukraine Exchange 1K Bodies of Soldiers
items.content_html: Russia returned the bodies of 1,000 Ukrainian soldiers while receiving the bodies of 24 Russian soldiers in exchange, authorities said.

source.name: The Moscow Times - Independent News From Russia

items.title: Trump-ally Grenell threatens German journalist with visa withdrawal
items.content_html: Will the US government tighten the conditions for German journalists working in the United States? A heated debate has erupted following the killing of US-influencer Charlie Kirk.

items.title: Can NATO stop Russian drone incursions?
items.content_html: After recent drone incursions into Polish and Romanian airspace, NATO has launched Operation Eastern Sentry to strengthen its eastern flank. How serious is the threat from Russia? And can NATO deter future provocations?

items.title: How Trump tariffs are lowering food prices in Brazil, Mexico
items.content_html: US tariff policy is having unexpected consequences for consumers — in some places. Coffee is becoming cheaper in Brazil, and in Mexico tomatoes are less expensive. US shoppers, meanwhile, are facing rising grocery bills.

items.title: Germany updates: Merz visits Spain amid Israel differences
items.content_html: Germany's Friedrich Merz has met with Spanish PM Pedro Sanchez in Madrid, with one big dividing issue between the two. Plus, the German government gained Bundestag approval for its annual budget.

items.title: German fears: Rising cost of living tops list of concerns
items.content_html: The rising cost of living is again the top cause of distress for Germans, according to a long-running survey. But despite the war in Ukraine, inflation and Donald Trump, Germans are noticeably less fearful.

items.title: Bella Ciao: Protest song in focus after Charlie Kirk killing
items.content_html: A look at the evolution of the Italian protest anthem, from its opaque origins to TikTok remixes and feminist marches.

items.title: US Federal Reserve cuts interest rate for first time in 2025
items.content_html: The widely expected cut of a quarter percentage point comes amid economic pressures ranging inflation and tariffs to sluggish job growth. Two more cuts are expected before the end of the year.

items.title: Kenya: Fraud scandal robs millions of health care, pensions
items.content_html: Kenya's pension and health insurance systems were meant to bring people dignity in old age. But fraud, delays and broken promises have left retirees and patients paying with their savings — and even their lives.

items.title: Trump at Windsor: Pomp, protest and the ghost of Jeffrey Epstein
items.content_html: Anti-Trump protesters in the UK get creative as King Charles III hosts Donald Trump for his second UK state visit.

items.title: How NIL money changes the game for German basketball
items.content_html: Germany's national basketball teams are enjoying a golden era, but are there concerns domestically that NIL money from US colleges might impact future generations.

items.title: Life in Germany: Free universities, health insurance and paid vacations?
items.content_html: DW's Berlin Fresh and The Washington Post Universe's TikTok teams collaborate to explore the perks of living in Berlin and Germany.

items.title: Germany updates: Get ready for big reforms, Merz says
items.content_html: Chancellor Merz says Germany needs to address "nothing less than the future of our country" as lawmakers debate the budget. Meanwhile, a suspect in the disappearance of Maddie McCann has been released from prison.

items.title: Eurovision: Countries to boycott if Israel competes
items.content_html: The Eurovision Song Contest is supposed to be apolitical. But Israel is now at the center of calls for boycott and protests, due to the ongoing war in the Gaza Strip.

items.title: Cancellation of Israeli conductor's concert: The problem with cultural boycotts
items.content_html: The cancellation of a Munich Philharmonic Orchestra concert in Belgium over its Israeli conductor Lahav Shani has sparked outrage in Germany. But how does this incident compare to other cases?

items.title: Is the green hydrogen dream over?
items.content_html: Clean, green hydrogen energy has long been hyped as the key to decarbonizing big industries like steel. But as projects are cancelled and investments dry up, what went wrong?

items.title: The 2025 solar storm peak. Should we be worried?
items.content_html: If strong enough, solar storms could wipe out our internet infrastructure. They disrupt aviation signals and, for example, the smooth running of petroleum pipelines in Nigeria.

items.title: "Arde Gaza": 600 000 Palestiniens mourront brûlés?
items.content_html: Fumer autour de Ciudad de Gaza après un bombardement israélien, mardi, au début de l'offensive foncière sur la capitale de la bande.

items.title: Why TV weather forecasters are targeted by online hate
items.content_html: An email death threat marked the beginning of the end of one meteorologist's job. Experts say climate misinformation and conspiracy theories are fueling online hate.

items.title: Is Europe prepared for winter despite lower gas supplies?
items.content_html: Europe's energy crisis may be fading, but Donald Trump's tariff threats on Russian gas buyers loom large. With no gas transiting through Ukraine this winter, can the continent afford to breathe a sigh of relief?

items.title: Jewish life in Germany: Merz gives emotional speech
items.content_html: The Central Council of Jews in Germany is marking its 75th anniversary under the shadow of rising antisemitism.

items.title: What to know about the 2025-26 Champions League
items.content_html: The new Champions League season is here and with it new teams, new kick-off times and a new chance for the Bundesliga.

items.title: Film icon Robert Redford dies at 89
items.content_html: Robert Redford, the director, actor, and activist has died at his home in Utah. Redford rose to fame in films like "Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid" and "All the President's Men."

items.title: Crime statistics: How safe is life in Germany?
items.content_html: Cases of drug trafficking, knife crime and violence on the streets are frequently reported in the German media. But is crime on the rise? And how does Germany compare internationally?

items.title: India and Pakistan stoked for long-awaited javelin clash
items.content_html: India and Pakistan are cricketing nations. But recent Olympic gold medals won by Neeraj Chopra and Arshad Nadeem in the javelin have fans on both sides anticipating the World Athletics Championships like never before.

items.title: How the watermelon became a Palestinian protest symbol
items.content_html: At pro-Palestinian demonstrations, the symbol of the watermelon is everywhere. Artist Sliman Mansour explains how the idea for the symbol goes back to the 1980s and was inspired, ironically, by an Israeli officer.

items.title: Germany state elections: AfD makes gains, Greens fall behind
items.content_html: The conservative CDU remains the strongest party after local elections in North Rhine-Westphalia. However, the far-right Alternative for Germany tripled its 2020 results. The Greens have emerged as the clear losers.

items.title: Trump turns crypto king — but at what cost?
items.content_html: Donald Trump has made billions from the Nasdaq debut of crypto startup World Liberty Financial. With his sons in charge and favorable policies in play, critics see a troubling mix of presidential power and personal gain.

items.title: Fentanyl: Germany prepares for synthetic drugs crisis
items.content_html: The opioid fentanyl, the main cause of drug-related deaths in the US, has arrived on the streets of Germany. In the western city of Essen, a pilot project called "so-par" is focusing on prevention.

items.title: Africa sees space as 'a means to an end'
items.content_html: When the African Space Agency opened in April, spacefaring countries like Egypt, Nigeria and South Africa came together for the first time. But they have been collaborating with Europe and China for decades.

items.title: What to expect during Donald Trump's visit at Windsor Castle
items.content_html: As King Charles III hosts Donald Trump for his second UK state visit, expect pomp, protocol and perhaps even meme-worthy missteps.

items.title: Experts fired by President Trump revive popular climate website
items.content_html: After cuts by US President Donald Trump forced the closure of the popular climate.gov website, experts have launched an independent successor. They say climate literacy is important in Trump's war against science.

items.title: Germany crowned EuroBasket champions
items.content_html: Reigning world basketball champions Germany have beaten Turkey in the final to win the European championship.

items.title: Germany: Merz's CDU set to win in NRW, AfD makes big gains
items.content_html: While the CDU is set for victory, the far-right AfD has tripled its share of voters in North Rhine-Westphalia since the last local elections in Germany's most populous state, early estimates show. DW has more.

items.title: Crocodile wrestling influencer flouts wildlife rules
items.content_html: American influencer and self-styled "Real Tarzann" is being investigated for illegally wrestling wild crocodiles in northern Australia. Critics say animals are suffering to create viral content.

items.title: The prison economy: Behind bars, everyone's making money
items.content_html: The world spends hundreds of billions yearly to punish offenders, with little return beyond more crime and less hope. DW examines how private contractors, organized crime gangs and inmates exploit prison for profit.

items.title: New study: Cannabis threatens fertility for women
items.content_html: A Canadian study has shown that cannabis can have a negative impact on female fertility and the success of IVF treatments. But German experts say more research is needed on factors like age and consumption habits.

items.title: Germany: Legacy of Nazi Nuremberg Laws 90 years later
items.content_html: In 1935, the Nazis under Adolf Hitler introduced laws to discriminate against Germany's Jewish population, culminating in the Holocaust. Experts warn that the deadly ideology behind the laws has not been overcome.

items.title: L'horreur du monde s'inscrit dans un pied de page
items.content_html: Le Nasser de deux ans, dans un hôpital Jan Yunis (Gaza).Son père le regarde peu de temps avant sa mort.

items.title: Germany: Police seize 400 kilograms of cocaine at Hamburg port
items.content_html: Customs officials were alerted after dock workers spotted two men behaving suspiciously. Both suspects have been arrested.

items.title: East Germany's Plattenbau: Divisive architecture in the spotlight
items.content_html: A cheap way to manage the housing shortage in former GDR cities, the prefab concrete buildings were long derided for their monotony. Their cultural legacy is now being explored anew.

items.title: Par une défense européenne plus intégrée
items.content_html: Les avions de combat F-16 dans un défilé militaire à Varsovie, en août dernier.

items.title: Kate, Furtado, Baerbock: Why trolling is sexist
items.content_html: A princess, a pop star and a politician — Kate Middleton, Nelly Furtado and Annalena Baerbock — have all experienced online harassment because of their appearance. Experts explain why this is no coincidence.

items.title: Boris Becker's new book: 'Wimbledon is partly to blame'
items.content_html: The former tennis superstar has written a book about his time in prison in the UK. Boris Becker uses "Inside" to write about his time behind bars, portraying himself as both a fighter and a victim.

items.title: Germany cleans up illegal trash dumped across the Czech border
items.content_html: A now bust German company illegally dumped hundreds of tons of hazardous waste in Czech municipalities. Authorities of both countries have been left to clean up the mess.

items.title: Should German schools stop teaching classics like Goethe?
items.content_html: German society is diverse, and so are its students. But diversity in the classroom is not reflected in the content of the courses. Students and teachers argue it should be.

items.title: Luka Doncic: Slovenia's polarizing NBA superstar
items.content_html: Germany have defeated Slovenia and Luka Doncic to reach the semifinals of EuroBasket 2025. The Los Angeles Lakers star may be virtually unstoppable, but he does have his weaknesses.

items.title: Spanish legal case leads fight against livestock pollution
items.content_html: A Spanish court ruling on pollution from industrial pig farming could have far-reaching implications for how animals are kept across Europe.

items.title: Dealing with loss: When loved ones take their own lives
items.content_html: According to the World Health Organization, one in every 100 deaths worldwide is by suicide. How do those left behind cope?

items.title: Bombes israéliennes à propos de Doha: avec des amis comme celui-ci ...
items.content_html: Capturez la vidéo de l'apparition du Premier ministre du Qatar, Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman bin Jassim Al Thani, mardi à Doha.

items.title: NASA rover discovers potential signs of ancient life on Mars
items.content_html: The discovery is among the strongest evidence yet that the red planet may have once harbored life. . However, scientists say more study is needed, ideally in labs on Earth.

items.title: IAA: Why VW and other carmakers are changing their EV designs
items.content_html: Electric cars are supposed to be the future. So why are German carmakers now taking a page from past designs? Steven Beardsly reports from the IAA Mobility show in Munich.

items.title: Germany's state-owned KfW bank linked to rights violations
items.content_html: The government's development bank is accused of backing harmful projects in emerging markets. Instead of uplifting communities, a new report says investments fail to protect human rights and silence those who speak out.

items.title: Du Kissinger
items.content_html: Ursula von der a lu dans son discours devant le Parlement européen, à Strasbourg, ce mercredi.

items.title: Space law crisis: Outer space security in an insecure world
items.content_html: If we can't get along on Earth, how will we ever get along in space, right? Experts told DW there are reasons to be optimistic.

items.title: EU to slash food and fast fashion waste
items.content_html: EU lawmakers have given a final green light to a law on slashing the mountains of food wasted in Europe each year, and curbing the environmental impact of fast fashion.

items.title: Did AI save Google from being broken apart by regulators?
items.content_html: The growing power of artificial intelligence was a deciding factor in a court's decision not to break up Google and its Chrome search browser. It is another reminder of the expanding influence of AI.

items.title: Could France's economic turmoil spark eurozone debt crisis?
items.content_html: The collapse of the French government over its inability to bring austerity measures through parliament is raising fears that the debt of the EU's second-largest economy is spinning out of control.

items.title: Young German authors embark on cultural US road trip
items.content_html: Goethe-Institut USA, which promotes German culture abroad, is sending Sonali Beher and Iven Yorick Fenker on a four-week road trip from New York to Houston to deepen the bond between both nations.

items.title: Coca-Cola rebrands products in Germany amid US image crisis
items.content_html: As the global reputation of US brands slips, some US firms are turning to unusual marketing strategies. Coca-Cola, for instance, is now promoting itself as a "German product."

items.title: Egypt, Sudan worry about water as Ethiopia's huge new dam opens
items.content_html: Ethiopia has high hopes for its Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam, which is expected to double the nation's electricity capacity. But the mega dam has long been a source of tension with neighbors Sudan and Egypt.

items.title: Germany bounce back with win vs. Northern Ireland
items.content_html: After their football World Cup qualifying campaign got off to a disastrous start, Germany responded with a win over Northern Ireland.

items.title: OpenAI under fire: Can chatbots ever truly be child-safe?
items.content_html: Did ChatGPT play a role in a US 16-year-old’s suicide? That's what the family claims in court against OpenAI. What exactly makes chatbots so risky?

items.title: Bauhaus Dessau celebrates centennial amid far-right attacks
items.content_html: The Bauhaus in Dessau is marking its 100th year with a focus on sustainable building as Germany's far-right AfD party uses the anniversary to attack the movement.

items.title: Will BRICS boom under Trump's watch?
items.content_html: BRICS nations will meet virtually next week to coordinate trade retaliation against the US. Has Donald Trump’s tariff blitz on top emerging economies sparked a stronger alliance among his biggest rivals?

items.title: Nazi-looted art: Who owns this expressionist painting?
items.content_html: A legal dispute over ownership of a painting by the German artist Paula Modersohn-Becker could be the final case before a Nazi-looted art commission. A controversial new restitution procedure will replace it.

items.title: Blood Moon: What makes a total lunar eclipse
items.content_html: A total lunar eclipse makes the moon shine with all the sunrises and sunsets on Earth — at the same time. But how? The moon is in Earth's shadow! Here's what’s going on.

items.title: Bundesliga: Can expanded league help competition?
items.content_html: The Women's Bundesliga has expanded to 14 clubs this season but in the last 12 years only two sides have been in contention for the title. While women's football in Germany is growing, it still lags behind the UK and US.

items.title: Germany suffer shock World Cup qualifying loss to Slovakia
items.content_html: Germany's 2026 World Cup qualifying campaign got off to a disastrous start as they suffered a deserved 2-0 defeat to Slovakia. Furious head coach Julian Nagelsmann questioned his team's mentality.

items.title: IAA: German automakers need to step on the gas to stay relevant
items.content_html: As the International Mobility Show opens in Munich, the German car industry is facing roadblocks on many sides. That's why manufactures are polishing up to prove they are ready to conquer the future of modern mobility.

items.title: Dystopian futures and Gaza tragedy in focus at Venice
items.content_html: As the 2025 Venice Film Festival draws to a close, it will be remembered for films that bravely reflect on the wars and politics of the time — and the impact of technology on the future.

items.title: Giorgio Armani, the minimalist, perfectionist fashion icon
items.content_html: Fashion designer Giorgio Armani launched his career in the 70s and quickly built up a fashion empire synonymous with elegance, quality and individuality. He has died at the age of 91 in Milan, Italy.

items.title: Fires in Spain and Portugal fueled by climate change
items.content_html: Wildfires caused devastation in Spain and Portugal this summer. Scientists say that rising global temperatures caused by burning fossil fuels has made the deadly fires 40 times more likely.

items.title: Desalination doesn't have to be bad for the environment
items.content_html: Drinking from the sea is essential to securing water supply but often has negative environmental impacts. Scientists say they can be minimized with careful planning and process.

items.title: Landslides and mudslides: Why they happen
items.content_html: Non-stop rain in Sudan caused a landslide to cover an entire village. The science of these natural disasters is simple. Preventing them is possible.

items.title: How humans made chickens grow and foxes shrink
items.content_html: Archeologists in southern France have studied bones spanning 8,000 years to reveal how humans caused domestic animals to grow in overall size, while wild animals shrank.

items.title: Digital taxes put US-EU trade talks under pressure
items.content_html: Trump is now threatening retaliation over EU tech rules, shaking the bloc’s 15% tariff deal. Lacking China’s rare earths leverage, Brussels is scrambling for countermeasures — what cards can it still play?

items.title: Sex testing in athletics a setback to science?
items.content_html: Former Spanish hurdler Maria Jose Martinez-Patino knows better than most about genetic testing, having missed out on a chance at the Olympics as a result of it. She spoke to DW about World Athletics' new regulations.

items.title: Bundesliga: Leverkusen sack coach ten Hag after two games
items.content_html: Former Manchester United head coach Erik ten Hag has been sacked by Bayer Leverkusen after only 62 days in charge and one defeat.

items.title: Why some countries want fewer public holidays
items.content_html: Some governments have proposed reducing public holidays, claiming it helps budgets and boosts growth. However, counter-arguments suggest that productivity is not just about days worked and that time off is important.

items.title: Germany's road to 2026 World Cup begins: What to know
items.content_html: The German national team has six games to play in 2025. The plan is to win them all and secure early qualification for the 2026 FIFA World Cup, but injuries and struggles against top teams cast something of a shadow.

items.title: How much screen time is safe for children?
items.content_html: In a world full of smartphones, tablets, and computers, how much media time is acceptable at what stage of life? Though there's little data on the issue, there are still a few principles on which most experts agree.

items.title: MLS star Müller settling in to 'village' life in Vancouver
items.content_html: Thomas Müller seems to be settling in well at the first club he has known apart from Bayern Munich. For a one-club man until a few weeks ago, he also seems to be truly embracing a new city and culture.

items.title: Nick Woltemade: Who is Germany's new Premier League star?
items.content_html: The young Germany striker, who was of great interest to Bayern Munich this summer, has left Stuttgart for Newcastle.

items.title: Dissident Belarusian sports official thought to be in Russia
items.content_html: Anatol Kotau has been unreachable for over a week. Those who know him suspect foul play, with the Belarusian secret service warning dissidents of retribution.

items.title: India vs. US: Who stands to lose most in the trade dispute?
items.content_html: US tariffs on Indian goods have risen to 50%, one of the highest rates in the world. The trade row between two of the world's biggest economies could have serious consequences for both.

items.title: Hurricane Katrina left lasting legacy for youngest survivors
items.content_html: Twenty years after Hurricane Katrina, survivors who lived through the storm as children are still reckoning with a city transformed — and the stories of loss and trauma they never got to tell.

items.title: Why I tried antidepressants to treat my chronic pain
items.content_html: Antidepressants treat depression and other mental conditions. But some people say the drugs ease physical aches, too. The evidence, however, is sobering.
